Award.AwardTitle: Static and Dynamical Aspects of String Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Savdeep Sethi at the University of Chicago.

The origins of space and time are one of the enduring mysteries of nature. Did space and time emerge in some kind of Big Bang? Will the universe end in a Big Crunch? Can we sensibly describe these singular highly quantum states of nature? In order to answer such basic questions about the nature of space and time, we need a quantum theory of gravity. String theory remains the best candidate for such a theory. In his research, Professor Sethi aims to explore static and dynamical aspects of string theory and quantum field theory. The static aspects include new ways of curling up the extra dimensions of string theory to arrive at a four-dimensional universe. These new types of compactification are closely tied to the dynamics of chiral gauge theory in two dimensions. The dynamical aspects include the study of stringy domain walls. These walls are bubbles of inflating space-time, quite similar to the conventional branes of string theory, which offer the possibility of a holographic definition of quantum gravity in an accelerating universe.

This project is also expected to have significant broader impacts. Professor Sethi will involve graduate students and post-doctoral fellows in his research, thereby providing mentoring to junior physicists studying string theory and quantum field theory. He also intends to interact with high-school students and undergraduates through continued participation in the Chicago REU program and the Space Explorers inner-city K-12 enrichment program. The final aspect of the broader impacts comes from improved interdisciplinary ties with both cosmologists and mathematicians through lectures at schools and workshops, through direct collaboration, and by organizing workshops at the interface between these disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why does our universe appear to be accelerating? Did space and time emerge in some kind of Big Bang? Will the universe end in a Big Crunch? To answer such questions requires an understanding of how quantum mechanics and gravity are reconciled. String theory provides such a reconciliation. The research goals of this project centered on several broad topics, involving both static and dynamical aspects of string theory.  

The first major theme centered on developing a deeper understanding of the many ways in which string theory or M-theory can produce a four-dimensional universe from an eleven-dimensional universe. This involves a choice of space on which to compactify the theory along with backgrounds for the stringy analogues of electric and magnetic fields. Some of the main outcomes of this project involved identifying the ingredients needed to produce compactifications of M-theory and type IIA string theory with background fluxes, and the relations between the choice of fluxes and supersymmetry in the heterotic string. The outcomes also included a closely related set of results concerning how to describe flux vacua of the heterotic string, and their relation to chiral gauge theory. This topic involves a beautiful interplay between the physics of chiral gauge theory and the mathematics of generalized geometries. 

Another major research direction was the study of domain wall solutions of string theory and quantum field theory as a potential alternative to the standard compactification paradigm. The advantage of this approach is that the constructions have the potential to provide a holographic description of accelerating universes. During the course of this investigation, numerous new questions emerged, including very classical unanswered questions from field theory, which are still being explored.  

In a similar vein, new no-go results ruling out constructions of accelerating universes in string theory were developed from both a space-time and world-sheet perspective. These results have been extremely useful for shedding light on the many proposed constructions of the multiverse. 

In a very different direction involving effective field theory, the relation between global anomalies and the chiral vortical effect of interest in many physical systems was described. This analysis even provides a potentially experimentally measurable prediction from a global anomaly.

The final topic studied is one of classical field theory and the emergence of the Dirac-Born-Infeld action from lumps in gravity. Quite remarkably, gravity automatically knows about both the Dirac action and the Born-Infeld non-linear theory of electromagnetism. This approach is currently being applied to the more mysterious chiral tensor theory found in six space-time dimensions. 

The broader impacts of the project centered mainly on two areas: the first involved providing research opportunities to undergraduates, including participation in the Chicago REU program and training an REU student. There were also several graduate students and postdoctoral fellows involved in the project. The second area involved improving interdisciplinary ties with both cosmologists and mathematicians through lectures at school and workshops, through direct collaboration, and by organizing workshops like the GRC workshop on "Cosmic Origin and Cosmic Fate: From Big Bang to Dark Energy."
